case_vignette: A 26-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine physical exam. He is concerned about a burning sensation that he feels in his throat whenever he eats large meals and is concerned he may have esophageal cancer like his uncle. The patient has a past medical history of irritable bowel syndrome and constipation. His current medications include whey protein supplements, fish oil, a multivitamin, and sodium docusate. The patient is concerned about his performance in school and fears he may fail out. He recently did poorly on an exam and it has caused him significant stress. He also is worried that his girlfriend is going to leave him. The patient claims that he thought he was going to be an incredible doctor some day, but now he feels like a terrible person. The patient also states that he feels guilty about his grandfather's death which occurred 1 year ago and he often reexperiences the funeral in his mind. He regularly has trouble sleeping for which he takes melatonin. The patient has been praying every 4 hours with the hopes that this will make things go better for him.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a burning sensation in my throat whenever I eat large meals.
Have you had this symptom for a long time?
No, it hasn't been a long time; it's a recent concern.
Have you had any other symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, coughing, or hoarseness?
No, just the burning sensation when I eat large meals.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or eating habits?
No recent changes in my diet or eating habits.
Have you had any recent travel history or exposure to any new environments?
I haven't had any recent travel or exposure to new environments.
Have you had any recent stress or anxiety?
Yes, I've had significant stress about school performance and personal issues.
Have you had any recent changes in your weight or appetite?
No, I haven't had any changes in my weight or appetite.
Have you had any recent changes in your sleep patterns or sleep quality?
Yes, I've been having trouble sleeping regularly.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication or supplement intake?
No, there haven't been any recent changes to my medications or supplements.
Have you had any family history of similar symptoms?
I am concerned I may have something similar to my uncle who had esophageal cancer.
Final Diagnosis: Esophageal Cancer.
